thesis.description: This thesis represents an attempt to use empirical methods to analyze the campaign period preceeding the general election of 1965 as a way of gaining some factual insights into the basic problems which beset the Canadian federation between 1960 and 1965. Data was collected from three basic sources: public opinion surveys, a sample of election candidates, and the editorial columns of twenty Canadian daily newspapers. It is the contention of the author that the 1965 campaign and certain related events constitute a microcosm of the period 1960-1965 and that this period represents a unique phase in the history of Canadian federalism. Evidence is adduced to illustrate the essential nature of the twin crises of English-French and federal-provincial relations and to support thee hypothesis that, while destined to interact, each of these problems had its own independent origin and source of dynamism. Finally, it is argued that, because of increasing regionalism, serious faults within the party system and other factors, neither problem was handled satisfactorily during the period under study.
